summary.topic: a lot of you were part of nights and weekends season 4
summary.summary: guys were part of nights and weekends season 4, so you saw a lot of what i'll cover. it's good to review logistical stuff first. we'll open for questions at the end, but stop me anytime.

summary.topic: i am staven, and i do everything that hits the user at buildspace
summary.summary: i handle all user-facing designs at bills space, from hoodies to stickers, and the website. i'll be teaching 50-60% of DMW; jeffrey will cover the rest.

summary.topic: i do a lot of the story and writing stuff
summary.summary: i handle most of the story and writing at build space, especially narrative stuff. we work in a small room and all of us pitch in on everything, so welcome to dmw.

summary.topic: dmw stands for design, marketing, and writing
summary.summary: you guys know what it is: design, marketing, and writing. we truly believe these are some of the key elements.

summary.topic: these are key ingredients for getting your story out to the world
summary.summary: ingredients to get your story out to the world: be authentic, find your voice, engage with your audience, and use the right platforms. make sure to stay consistent and keep refining your message.

summary.topic: basic principles of design, marketing, and writing are very beneficial
summary.summary: you could be making music, films, apps, or a new YouTube channel. all those projects benefit greatly from understanding basic design, marketing, and writing principles. even knowing just the basics can take you far.

summary.topic: the basics can help close the gap between how you want to be perceived and how your audience perceives you
summary.summary: closing the gap between how you want to be perceived and how your audience actually sees you is crucial, especially at the stage you're in whether you're starting out or promoting a product. these sessions are about ensuring everyone is aligned and having a positive experience while sharing your story.

summary.topic: weekly sessions will cover lessons from past experiences
summary.summary: i've been in education for almost a decade and learned a lot from mistakes and experiences. we're sharing these lessons weekly to help you avoid or quickly recover from similar mistakes. sessions won't focus on hard skills like using framer or figma, but on broader learnings.

summary.topic: sessions will be more conceptual but with practical examples
summary.summary: conceptual, but we'll also have sessions where you can bring your projects and get tips on improving them. we're open book, so feel free to ask anytime.

summary.topic: feel free to ask questions and bring in your own work for feedback
summary.summary: if you have questions about our work, like how we made an asset or a site, we're always open to answer and even show you how it's done. balancing soft and hard skills is crucial, and incorporating inspiration is key.

summary.topic: inspiration is all around; take pictures of things that catch your eye
summary.summary: inspiration is everywhere, even when grabbing coffee at equator. take the hats there, for instance; they spark ideas.

summary.topic: capture unique designs or ideas and use them in your work
summary.summary: hats are cool, so i take pictures of them. same with this coffee bag—its art stands out, but it has some design mistakes to avoid. every time i look at the picture, i'm reminded of what not to do. it's like when you're browsing social media and saving things; it helps you learn.

summary.topic: keep screenshots for future reference; they can be very helpful
take inspiration from all kinds of media, including packaging and social media posts
summary.summary: imagine grabbing a sparkling water and seeing a standout can among all the plastic bottles. every time you stop at something while scrolling, think about what grabbed your attention – it helps build a keen eye. also, taking and indexing screenshots makes it easier to reference back, like when designing hats or hoodies; i do this with my workflow by using screenshots and pinterest boards, which can apply to any creative work.

summary.topic: it's important to be constantly inspired and to document it
summary.summary: basically, the key takeaway is to keep your eyes open for inspiration all the time. during the 11-week course, we'll stay adaptable and learn more about your needs after the first three weeks. this way, we can identify the challenges you're facing and adjust accordingly.

summary.topic: how you present your work can make a big difference
the first three weeks will focus on learning about you and your challenges
summary.summary: next week we'll start with marketing. i'll show examples from last time and help you improve. let's break it down and improve together.

summary.topic: the schedule will start with marketing, then writing, and then design
summary.summary: 101 with me and Jeffrey next week, then writing 101. design in the third week, which is your fourth week. 214 Valentine's Day special, and DMW 4 onwards will freestyle.

summary.topic: the fourth week onwards will be more flexible based on what we learn
summary.summary: based on what we’re learning, whether it’s telling better stories or reaching a bigger audience, we’ll cover all that. we’ll also break down what worked and what didn’t.

summary.topic: we will break down what worked and what didn’t from your examples
summary.summary: we'll show you guys why certain things worked and why they didn't, like analyzing viral content or discussing why some posts flopped. it's about brainstorming together and finding ways to improve. for example, a group of kids changed their profiles on twitter to something mysterious as part of an experiment almost two years ago, which we'll dive into further.

summary.topic: examples like imouth ey experiment show the power of viral content
summary.summary: during the time clubhouse was booming, vcs were eager to find the next big thing. a group tricked them into donating hundreds of thousands by promising priority on a waitlist if they contributed to certain causes. it was a viral experiment showing how easily people could be influenced, especially when hype around clubhouse was peaking.

summary.topic: another example is humane, a handheld pocket device making waves
summary.summary: it's a handheld pocket device with a camera, allowing you to ask it anything like chat GPT. it also has cellular connectivity for tasks like ordering door Dash using your voice. initially, the keynote had 2,000 subscribers and 100,000 views on its first day on YouTube.

summary.topic: analyzing viral trends can help you understand why they succeeded
summary.summary: they had 29.1k subscribers and 5 million views. after showcasing their product and keynote at CES, they skyrocketed to 60k pre-orders from an initial goal of 500. their timing was perfect, riding the hype of AI trends with an innovative AI hardware product priced at a non-subscription $199, which attracted a lot of attention. on top of that, teenage engineering designed its appealing physical appearance, leading to widespread talk on platforms like TikTok.

summary.topic: we will also cover mental models like "chopping wood and collecting sawdust"
summary.summary: gen z barbers on tik tok and instagram are blowing up, and someone asked me what they could do to get more business. i suggested simple things like putting a camera in the shop to film haircuts and giving hairstyle advice on youtube. even though he's busy cutting hair all day, recording conversations and doing before-and-after shots could still help grow an audience.

summary.topic: making mundane activities into content can help grow your audience
summary.summary: incorporate content into your workflows by making it interactive, like doing stories with chat and live streams. try things like offering discounts for before-and-after shots or having people tag you for funny reactions, and create entertaining content like continuous water spraying or spinning chairs. just make sure it's fun for you, as that energy will attract viewers.

summary.topic: consistency is key; keep your eyes open and don't be afraid to try things
summary.summary: streaming door dash deliveries on his bike can be a fun, interactive way to grow your audience without much extra effort. creators like drew walls, who faced criticism for repetitive, "cringe" content, later achieved success and validation when their videos gained massive attention, even leading to deals with major organizations. embracing seemingly "cringe" content with conviction can sometimes result in significant opportunities and recognition.

summary.topic: examples of viral ideas include day in the life videos and interactive content
summary.summary: open conversations about how to improve projects, share what worked and what didn't, and apply those lessons to new ideas. one suggestion was creating a site where strangers write letters to random recipients, which did moderately well. brainstorming ways to make projects viral included leveraging influencers, using creative formats like reels, printing and distributing letters, and integrating monetization strategies like selling books on Amazon, as well as using tech innovations like lip-syncing models for engaging content.

summary.topic: learning from others' viral content is a great way to improve your own
summary.summary: there's a problem where ai is making it hard to tell if rogan videos are real or generated. to reach different audiences, one could create bots mimicking high-profile figures or niche personas, and use them to generate content around various themes. there's potential in monetizing this by offering a service that turns youtube channels or podcasts into 24/7 interactive streams, generating interest with mundane or controversial clips.

summary.topic: don’t overcomplicate things; just optimize for time to ship
summary.summary: there's a trend of tiktokers reading to kids, which many parents are spending money on. you could have drake or other celebrities read to you, which is pretty cool. there's also tech allowing for ai cameos from celebs like taylor swift or bts, and students are improving these models for better results. one key lesson is to keep things simple and just pick a tool or path to start, focusing on how quickly you can get familiar and ship your project.

summary.topic: the internet provides immense leverage for creators
summary.summary: just get the concept clear in your head and go for it, optimizing for speed rather than perfection. the internet has massively changed how creators and builders distribute their work, making it easier than ever before. leverage online platforms like TikTok and Spotify to get noticed, and don't wait for perfection—just consistently put your work out there and learn from what catches attention. share your experiences and methods with a small group to help analyze and refine your approach.

summary.topic: posting consistently on any platform will help you find your audience
summary.summary: figure out where your audience is engaging, whether it's reals, next door, or facebook groups. for instance, next door is a neighborhood app with micro-communities. attention has shifted to reals on instagram, so you need to position yourself where the attention is.
